Running the SCoPex test doesn't mean that we will be undertaking solar geoengineering the next day. There's a very good chance that SCoPex could tell us that our initial ideas are wrong. Or it could hint at ways to do it more safely. (14/15)

As long as the choice is between SRM and cutting carbon, focus on cutting carbon. But if/when the choice is between SRM and billions of deaths around the world, I support trying SRM. And to reduce the risks that would come with SRM, I want to see it tested safely first. (13/15)

Let me be extremely clear: I DO NOT WANT HUMANKIND TO DEPLOY SOLAR GEOENGINEERING. The dangers would be immense. But I also recognize that, given our inability to do enough, fast enough, to cut carbon, we may find ourselves at a point of desperation. (12/15)

But here's the thing: we don't know exactly how to do SRM, and there may be options that look okay but turn out wrong once attempted. We need to test ahead of time. Not just to know what to do, but to know what *not* to do, too. That's why I support approval of SCoPex. (11/15)

A tourniquet is a terrible way to treat a bleeding wound. Even done properly, it could cause enormous damage to the body. But if the alternative is bleeding to death, a tourniquet is a less-bad option while you try to get better treatment. It's an act of desperation. (10/15)

I know some scientists who have been working on SRM for years. Not one of them thinks it's a good idea, but it's better (in their view) than temps hitting +3° or higher. And holding temps down could give us time to do the needed global decarbonization.

It's a tourniquet. (9/15)

But SRM geo is the only climate tool that could hold down or even reduce temperatures quickly. Everything else we can/must do takes time to have an impact. Not just years, sometimes centuries. 

So SRM is not a solution. If it's done, it would be an act of desperation. (8/15)

SRM geo holds the potential for enormous danger. It could alter global rainfall patterns, cause conflicts over unintended consequences, and a sudden cessation (due to conflict or accident) could cause temps to rebound very quickly. And SRM does nothing about carbon. (7/15)
